message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of pain and swelling near the lacrimal duct with expressible pus suggest dacrocystitis, which is an infection or inflammation of the lacrimal sac. Hordeolum presents with a painful lump or pimple on the eyelid, while both orbital and periorbital cellulitis produce diffuse erythema and swelling of the eyelid and surrounding tissues.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of pain and swelling near the lacrimal duct, with expressible pus when pressure is applied, suggest dacryocystitis. Hordeolum would present with external pain and erythema near the eyelid margin, while orbital cellulitis and periorbital cellulitis would show more significant symptoms such as proptosis, ophthalmoplegia, and vision changes, which are not observed in this patient. The recent orbital fracture may be a contributing factor, but is not the primary cause of the symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest dacrocystitis, which is an infection of the tear sac. The presence of expressible pus and pain/swelling near the lacrimal duct support this diagnosis. Hordeolum is also known as a stye and is usually seen on the eyelid margin rather than near the lacrimal duct. Orbital cellulitis and periorbital cellulitis are both infections of the eye and surrounding tissues, but they typically present with more severe symptoms such as fever, proptosis, and restricted eye movements. The lack of these symptoms in this patient makes those options less likely.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, especially the pus noted when pressure is applied, suggest Dacrocystitis, which is an infection of the lacrimal sac. Hordeolum would present with a painful, tender lump on the eyelid, and orbital cellulitis and periorbital cellulitis would present with more severe swelling, redness, and potentially fever. The recent orbital fracture is likely unrelated to the current symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The swelling near the lacrimal duct and the expressible pus suggest dacrocystitis, which is an infection of the lacrimal sac. Hordeolum is an infection of the eyelid, while periorbital and orbital cellulitis involve inflammation of the tissues around and within the orbit of the eye.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and physical exam findings suggest dacryocystitis, which is an inflammation of the lacrimal sac. Hordeolum, orbital cellulitis, and periorbital cellulitis may present with similar symptoms, but they are less likely given the location of the pain and swelling, and the presence of pus upon pressure.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest dacryocystitis, which is an inflammation or infection of the tear duct. The pus expressed upon pressure applied to the area is a characteristic finding of dacryocystitis. Hordeolum is a localized infection of the eyelid margin, while orbital and periorbital cellulitis are more severe infections involving the tissues and structures around the eye.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of expressible pus near the lacrimal duct indicates dacryocystitis. Hordeolum typically presents as a tender, erythematous, and well-circumscribed nodule whereas orbital and periorbital cellulitis typically present with erythema, edema, and warmth of the eyelid and surrounding tissue along with fever and leukocytosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Dacrocystitis is inflammation of the lacrimal sac, which results in pain and swelling near the lacrimal duct. The fact that pus is expressed when pressure is applied to the area suggests an infection. Hordeolum is a stye, which appears as a red, tender bump on the eyelid, but it is not located near the lacrimal duct. Orbital cellulitis and periorbital cellulitis refer to infections of the tissues around the eye, but they do not involve the lacrimal sac specifically.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The location of the pain and swelling near the lacrimal duct, along with expressible pus, suggests dacryocystitis. Hordeolum affects the eyelid, while orbital and periorbital cellulitis involve the tissues surrounding the eye and would likely show more significant findings on physical examination.
